courseInfo.departmentName: Information & Communication Technology / Electronics & Communication Engineering

rationale: Digital technology-the fastest growing technology has revolutionized the electronics industry. In most of the applications digital technology has replaced analogue technology. Digital logic is the heart of digital electronic circuits. A basic understanding of this subject is therefore essential to effective maintenance of the digital electronic devices. The study of this course will enable the students to test the working and rectify the faults of common digital circuits. The syllabus has been designed to make students know about fundamental principles of Digital Electronics and gain familiarity with the available IC chips.

courseOutcomes.description: Interpret various number systems and their conversions to binary number system, and understand binary arithmetic operations.
Implement simplified Boolean equations using logic gates.
Analyze & verify different combinational logic circuits.
Learn about different types of sequential logic circuits.
Classify various memories and logic families.

content: Introduction to various number systems: Binary, Octal, Decimal, Hexadecimal
Conversion from one number system to another and vice-versa
Binary arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication and division
1's and 2's Complement of binary number & subtraction using 1's and 2's complement method
Digital Logic Gates: Symbol, operation and truth-table of AND, OR, NOT, NAND, NOR, EX-OR, EX-NOR gates
Basic theorems and properties of Boolean algebra
Implementations of Boolean function using AND-OR-Invert logic gates
Universal Gates: NAND & NOR
Algebraic simplification of Boolean expression using Boolean algebra
Sum of Product (SOP) definition and Simplification of Boolean function using Karnaugh map (K-map) up to 4-variables
Don't care condition in K-map
Arithmetic Circuits: Design Half adder, full adder, half subtractor, full subtractor; Block diagram of parallel adder using half and full adder block (up to 4-bit)
Encoder (4:2, 8:3); Decoder (2:4, 3:8)
Multiplexers (2:1, 4:1, 8:1); De-multiplexers (1:2, 1:4, 1:8)
Binary to Gray and Gray to binary code converters up to 4 bits
Flip-flops: SR, D, JK, T, Master Slave JK
Triggering methods
Shift Registers: Classification - (i) Serial in serial-out, (ii) serial-in parallel-out, (iii) parallel-in serial-out and (iv) parallel-in parallel out
Counters: Ring Counter, Johnson Counter, 4 bit Asynchronous (Ripple) Counter, 4 bit Synchronous up/down Counter, BCD/Decade counter

courseContent.unitTitle: Introduction to Memories and logic families
content: Introduction and Types of Memory: RAM (SRAM, DRAM), ROM (PROM, EPROM, EEPROM)
Overview of different logic family Definitions: Fan in, Fan out, Noise margin, Propagation delay, Power dissipation, Figure of merit
Comparison of different logic families (TTL, CMOS, ECL)
E-waste Management of Digital ICs/Chips

practicalOutcomes.outcome: Build/Test the functionality of Basic and Advance Logic Gates
Build/Test 2 input basic logic gates using NAND gate
Build/Test 2 input basic logic gates using NOR gate
Build/Test logic circuits for De Morgan's theorems
Build/Test Full Adder Circuit using two half adders
Build/Test Full Subtractor Circuit using two half Subtractors
Build/Test a circuit to Convert 4 bit Binary to Gray Code using logic gates
Build/Test a circuit to Convert 4 bit Gray to Binary Code using logic gates
Build/Test the functionality of the SR and D Flip-Flop
Build/Test the functionality of the JK and T Flip-flops
Build/Test the working of the Shift Register/Ring counter
Build/Test the working of BCD Counter
Identify various semiconductor memories (RAM, ROM) from CPU and list their features/specifications
Identify various Digital Logic families and prepare characteristics comparison
